awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Hyperlocal and Hypertemporal Information in Mass Emergencies Events: Next Generation Crisis Informatics Data Collection and Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance the empirical study of crisis informatics by moving the extensive analytics developed for post processing of social media-based crisis information to the point of data collection to create a set of intelligent data collection techniques.  Crisis informatics is a multidisciplinary field combining human-computer interaction and social computing; its central tenet is that people use personal information and communication technology to respond to disaster in creative ways to cope with uncertainty. This research will reveal how people respond in disasters, both collectively and individually, by examining their digital traces. This will help create better emergency management practice and policy. The research will also advance the delivery of the information people need in disasters by leveraging the vast social media data sets that are produced during them. The safety of people and provision of emergency care as a function of improved situational awareness are the direct benefits of conducting this research.

Past research shows that people local to an event seek and provide information online to help themselves and each other, and that this information is highly localized and temporalized when compared to the global conversation that otherwise arises. Current techniques to derive useful information from the social media stream are limited because they usually cannot scale to the vast growth in social media production; they are often restricted to examining only the language of social media posts and not their metadata; and social media are often collected in ways that prohibit the kinds of analyses that are needed for deep exploration and re-use of the data. This research relies on the body of work that the investigators have empirically conducted on the nature of social media behavior in disasters, and incorporates those rigorous deductive and inductive analytical methods at the point of data collection of the social media streams. This will enable intelligent data collection that can perform real-time analysis that bore in on the hypertemporal and hyperlocal features of information communicated via social media. With agility and rigor, solutions developed in this research will be able to pursue multiple threads of emergent concern that will spawn multiple simultaneous data collection trajectories. This will better enable real-time analysis and visualization of what is happening in the social media record during disaster events as they unfold.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. Our research integrates findings from empirical research about social media communication during disaster events arising from weather and geologic hazards with natural language processing research and advanced software engineering approaches for improving representative data collection and analysis. We have also responded to public health crises that have emerged over the course of this grant (the Zika epidemic and the COVID-19 pandemic), which exhibit different information behaviors from weather and geologic hazards.

We engaged empirically with weather and emergency response practitioners on the kinds of temporalized and localized data they need to integrate into their distributed work activities for different kinds of hazards. In response to the pandemic, we extended the empirical research to include examination of how information was being shared. We found that some actors had tremendous influence on what was consumed by others especially in comparison to weather hazards. Messaging about the pandemic was amplified independent of message content, masking many temporal and locational cues about relevance. This demanded a new data collection and analytic strategy to identify relevant “sites of interaction” through the compounded construction of keywords from which to collect empirical data. 

The research examined how analysts collaborate over large disaster data sets of social media posts expressed in multiple languages. The data collection infrastructure included collecting contextualized data surrounding individual social media posts and integration of other low-level analysis techniques to apply to incoming data sets, as well as the front-end for interaction by analysts which supported detailed analytic workflows. We expanded data collection with specialized natural language processing techniques to multiple languages by using word embeddings and graph-based semi-supervised methods to extract disaster-related keywords.

Broader Impacts. This research has empirically tackled the study of serious weather, geologic and biohazardous events that have humanitarian consequences around the world, events that reverberate in both the physical and digital worlds. They require an integrated socio-computational approach for comprehensive, methodologically sound approaches to their data capture and analysis to understand how people seek, provide and–increasingly–disrupt timely and localized information. Junior and senior researchers from across disciplines have come together to work on these problems, yielding multiple publications, popular press articles, new knowledge provided to practitioners, advanced lessons that are offered in university classrooms, and new MS- and PhD-level scholars who are now working in computing fields in academia and industry to advance interdisciplinary approaches to inform socio-computational investigation of large-scale societal phenomena.
